 implementation of HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=467342474; y=w_u6MMrSobjuPHx61XWt3TyjBpEMG9NjNo9dazUdNxpF9jGIwBx6

Hello Oliver,

> Thanks for your positive feedback. :) I did consider submitting some of it for
> publication, but to be honest I didn't want to submit to a conference where
> I'd have to travel overseas due to climate change considerations (eg GECCO
> this year), and haven't gotten around to looking for other opportunities.

That's noble of you. There are definitely conferences in the states, as well
as journals, if you are interested.

> I don't specifically remember trying the "discrimination between complex
> non-solid shapes" experiments without incremental scaling, however I seem to
> remember per-generation performance being much better when starting with a
> higher resolution (but despite this the use of scaling reduced the total
> run-time of the experiments). I suppose that at higher resolutions the
> (representation of the) shapes become increasingly different (up to a point
> depending on the similarity and complexity of the images, anyway) and so it's
> easier to evolve a function that can differentiate between them.

Interesting. Thanks.

> I don't know how I forgot the 3D representation experiment you performed; I
> read that paper (at least once), but I guess some time before I wrote my
> thesis! I just had another look at it, and am wondering what the results would
> have been like for:
>  * differently engineered 3D representations, eg the "The HipIO joint was
> placed just below the HipFB joint in the Z dimension", what would have
> happened if these were more widely separated?, and

That would be interesting to try. There were so many different ways to
engineer 1D, 2D, and 3D representations that we did not have the time to try
them all. My code is available, however, so if you want to try your
suggestion that would be great. If you do, I'd enjoy hearing how it goes.

>  * randomised 3D representations.

We did do this. The results are in the paper in figure 6 (black vs. blue):
the 3D engineered representation significantly outperformed the 3D
randomized representation.

> Did you perform any other experiments (in large or small numbers) using 3D
> representations? This is an area I'd like to explore some more.

No. In fact, I originally expected the 3D to outperform 2D (which it did not
significantly do), so I think it would be interesting to try different 3D
representations and find out if I just happened to choose a poor one. Please
let us know if you do conduct such tests.

Congrats again on the great work.

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Computational Synthesis Laboratory
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune

**Call for papers! Generative and Developmental Systems Track, GECCO 2011
(Dublin). Deadline extended to Feb. 9th.**
